datasource: Parker, E. M., and Richard J. Hayward. 1985. 'A Concise Outline of Phonology and Morphology. Appendix A in E. M. Parker &  Richard J. Hayward, An Afar-English-French Dictionary. London: School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. pp. 214-297. abbrev. in :note with Page and Table number as 'PHpnnn-nnn-t' -- e.g.  'PH85p274-279-s' = 'Parker-Hayward1985 pp.274-279; table s'

Vowels.inventory: i e a o u; ii ee aa oo uu

geodemoTXT: Varieties and subdialects of Afar are spoken by more than a million individuals in Ethiopia, Djibouti, and Eritrea. It is very closely relateSaho.

termclusters.label: afr-morphVerb-TamStemForm-fak-
termclusters.note: PH85p257-22 :: This paradigm gives the form structure, affirmative and negative, for each of the 26 tam forms recognized by Hayward. In the absence of a detailed analysis, an approximate gloss (that of Hayward, in fact) is given for the affirmative forms. As example of each polarity-tam comination we give the 3msg form of the suffixing verb fak- open.
terms: -inn-subordinate-y, 'if he had opened / had he opened'
en perf, 'he was opening / used to open /had been opening'
sug perf, 'he was opening / used to open /had been opening'
wa-, 'he is intending / about to open'
